subject: Add multi-host postcode support
commitMessage:
Add multi-host postcode support

These changes add the multiple host postcode implementation.
In addition to the LPC snoop the postcode can be read via D-Bus
interface.The same is displayed in seven segment display thorough
GPIO lines.

The design can be refered at
   https://gerrit.openbmc-project.xyz/c/openbmc/docs/+/35065

Tested:

 Verified in Facebook Tiogapass & Yosemitev2 platforms.

1.The postcode displayed in the seven segment corresponding to the
  host position selected in the frontpanel of Facebook
  yosemitev2(4 host).

2.The postcode history is verified in the respective host directory
     "/var/lib/phosphor-post-code-manager/hostX(1,2,3,4)".

Signed-off-by: Kumar Thangavel <thangavel.k@hcl.com>
Change-Id: Id79ad00652bfedd319d3b8ccf1aafbdc60b33d86

Absolutely not.  There is no assurance that the host numbers are 1-N.  This is why we have the HOST_INSTANCES variable.
Ack. Missed to change HOST_INSTANCE as got this comment in meta-phosphor patch. Will update in the PS.
'const' is redundant when you already have 'constexpr'

Is there even a reason to call this "ipmi snoop"?  That seems like the implementation, but this code would work 100% the same if there were a (for example) PLDM implementation of the same interface, right?
There is a sdbusplus helper for PropertiesChanged signals, please use that rather than creating your own.
Why are we restricting post codes to 1 byte?  AMD uses 32 or 64 bit post codes.
This implies that 0xFF is an invalid post code.  Is that true?

Is there a good reason to mix using the sdbuspp-generated classes and the boost code?  This is a little confusing to me.


Why do we need this async_get?  Can't we simply listen to a PropertyChanged signal for the selector?
How do we know this ends up being the service name?  Can we use mapper instead of hard-coding service names?
Suggest setting [[nodiscard]] on this so that the bug that you have on line 173 doesn't happen.

Rather than control these GPIOs from userspace like this, there was once a proposal for a 7-segment display driver in the kernel.  Can you follow up what happened with it?

https://lore.kernel.org/openbmc/CANsWYUW3sdbUguaOOMLkvbaTOHsCMBo8n0CDpVYiSkbZBuRThQ@mail.gmail.com/

I think the '7seg.cpp' is also related to this.

This driver is related to 7seg only. But they are using 16 bits for displaying values in 7 Seg.
they use abcdefg pins of 7 segment. But our LCD debugcard needs 8 bits only. We can't use this driver.
GPIOs like this should be defined in https://github.com/openbmc/docs/blob/master/designs/device-tree-gpio-naming.md.
You are getting a lambda here and then doing nothing with it.  I suspect that isn't what you intended.

I don't understand how this is expected to work.  You did an async call on line 169 to get the latest value of the selector, but you do nothing here to wait for it, so you are guaranteed to always be using the *old* value of the selector, aren't you?

Don't you need to do something to update the postCodeDisplay to the current host whenever the selector changes as well?  Otherwise the 7 seg display will continue to display a post code for the previously selected host, which is pretty confusing to a human.

I'm relatively confused here.  Aren't we missing this whole transformation?

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seven-segment_display#Hexadecimal
Ack. Our LCD Debug card converts 8 bits data and directly displaying the postcodes in the 7seg display.

Facebook server uses the removable Debug card which has the 7seg display.

The Debug card has micro controller which is responsible to receive the postcode from the BMC via GPIO and converts into hex value.

Please refer the below link.
https://www.opencompute.org/documents/facebook-ocp-debug-card-with-lcd-spec_v1p0
I don't think this is accurate anymore.  Is it really "TOTAL HOST" or is it a per-instance number for this daemon?
Does this break current users in any way?  Are there any recipe updates or service file updates we need to do to make sure this is '0' by default?
Yes. In the recipe, they should have OBMC_HOST_INSTANCES by default as "0".

How do you know they are listed "1 2 3" and not "3 2 1"?

What happens if the list is "1 3 5"?  Do we end up creating useless handlers for 2/4?

No. Count the instances based on the delimiter(space).
"1 2 3" and "3 2 1"  = 3.
"1 3 5" = 3. 

Two terms : total number of host and instance.
total number of host - based on the delimiter we can count.
Instance - we need to parse from the obmc-host-instances.

Now, we are getting both number of host and instances
This makes it seem like you should #ifdef around device on line 183 also, right?
There is some bad behavior here that '-d foo' ends up causing '-v' when ENABLE_IPMI_SNOOP is on (inadvertent fall-through).

Why do we have two different constants here?  Can you refactor this so that 'lpcsnoop' and 'ipmisnoop' both append the appropriate host value from `-h`?  Please refactor this code so that the 'lpcsnoop' is all inside a function similar to the one here for 'postCodeIpmiHandler'.  I think this will make it so that the only difference is which handler function you're calling here.

Why?

And why are we mixing printf and cout?
It appears that only ipmisnoop.hpp utilizes libgpiod.  Should this (and/or libgpiodcxx) only be used when the ipmisnoop is enabled?
Why do we need both?  Doesn't libgpiodcxx depend on libgpiod itself?
C++ functions like line bulk objects needs libgpiodcxx. If we provide only libgpiod, it not accepts C++ API's.

That tells me why we need libgpiodcxx, but do we also need libgpiod?  It seems like you should only need one of the dependencies.  dbus-sensors, for instance, also does GPIO access but only uses libgpiodcxx.

Ack. libgpiodcxx only used now. libgpiod is not needed and also removed in earlier Patch-sets.
Sorry. Missed to reply this comment.

Since the code already has 'lpcsnoop', I would suggest that 'snoop' is not a great name for this.

Should ipmi and lpc snoop be incompatible or can both be enabled at the same time?  You may need two different options for 'lpcsnoop' and 'ipmisnoop' (and use some meson settings to ensure only one can be set) or else have a single 'snoop' option which is configurable with a set `{ 'lpc', 'ipmi' }`.

Do we need to do any refactoring to the code so that lpcsnoop is disabled when ipmisnoop is enabled?

Single snoop option configure with lpc or ipmi.

Do we need to do any refactoring to the code so that lpcsnoop is disabled when ipmisnoop is enabled?  --> No I think, Based on the compiler option any one snoop should be enabled.
It appears that the rest of the options have taken to use dashes and not underscores.
cleanup to fit line limit. Same with the lines below.

Yes. constexpr with std::string is not working. It should be literal. 

Getting the below error.

error: the type ‘const string’ {aka ‘const std::__cxx11::basic_string’} of ‘constexpr’ variable ‘ipmiSnoopObject’ is not literal.

should also be `constexpr char*` for consistency.

and `PropertiesIntf` should be camcelCase -> propertiesIntf
duplicate from snoop.hpp? can we just include that folder? or refactor it to make it easier.

flip the logic to save horizontal spaces.

if (valPropMap == msgData.end()){
 log error
  return
}

other code...

can delete? or set to default
most of the new headers here looks like might not be used? also for the used one it should also be in `#ifdef ENABLE_IPMI_SNOOP`?

does this need to be global?

It seems like it is just used in one function, maybe we can just pass a span to the function instead?
I would prefer this being std::string_view

should be `const std::string&` to avoid copy.

Prefer `std::string_view` instead.
Updated with const std::string&.  If we use std::string_view, not able to convert or concat with std::string.
no need for the else since you return in the statement above.
constexpr with std::string is not working as mentioned above.
same here. No need for the else.

for vector it should be `const std::vector<std::string>&` since we don't want to modify it in the function.

Since this is read-only, prefer `std::span<std:string>` instead.

Updated with `const std::vector<std::string>&` .

std::span doesn't have emplace_back(), push_back(), insert() operation to insert the elements into span.  Please suggest on this.

you are not adding anything in this function and shouldn't matter. (unless I missed it)

const std::vector<std::string>& -> std::span<std::string> should just work.

Also `const std::string&` could also be `std::string_view`

Updated with std::span<std::string>.

not able to use std::string_view. Getting compilation issue. If we use std::string_view, not able to convert or concat with std::string.
const since you don't need to update it. But I would just use ' ' directly in the find function.
probably the last set of comments. lets make all of the changes for `ENABLE_IPMI_SNOOP` only and will not affect existing systems.
should only be used in ENABLE_IPMI_SNOOP

I was thinking to move this before the other block of code

and remove the compile flag for `#ifndef ENABLE_IPMI_SNOOP` so that we always build it but that's probably not a good idea.

Let's revert this and just make sure that return the error code with

```
return postCodeIpmiHandler(ipmiSnoopObject, snoopDbus, bus, host);
```

Done. 
Moved #ifdef ENABLE_IPMI_SNOOP block before #ifndef ENABLE_IPMI_SNOOP and return. Not removed #ifndef ENABLE_IPMI_SNOOP block. because some variables are declared in that blocks. if we remove this getting compilation issue.

Pls let me know if any changes required here.
this forces it to be required and it used to be optional.
Ack. Will update this to without optional.

prefer not get_options('snoop').disabled()

this will include enabled and auto

can we just append host-instances to SNOOPD_ARGS and make it optional. So that it will work like before without it.

and make `snoop-device` dependent on `snoop`.

Added host-instances to SNOOPD_ARGS with optional. 

snoop, snoop-device are different meson options. snoop is used to enable IPMISNOOP and snoop-device refers to linux module snoop-device.

I was thinking of 

```
snoopd_args = '-b ' + get_option('post-code-bytes').to_string()
if not get_option('snoop').disabled()
  add_project_arguments('-DENABLE_IPMI_SNOOP',language:'cpp')
  snoopd_args += '-h ' + get_option('host-instances')
endif

if get_option('snoop-device') != ''
  snoopd_args += ' -d /dev/' + get_option('snoop-device')
endif
conf_data.set('SNOOPD_ARGS', snoopd_args)
```

and in the service file just have

```
ExecStart=@bindir@/snoopd @SNOOPD_ARGS@
```
like before.

This allow us to support exiting systems while supporting the new change.

value: 'disabled'

so we don't use it by default.

Just looked over the functionality and just wondering if we can expand on top of the 7seg.cpp?

If not, we can take a closer look next time. Last set of comments and we can submit for now and can clean it up if needed.

In LPC snoop, Some hardware Soc itself handles the display part and send to 7seg display. If BCD code received, the driver itself take care of display part in 7seg.

In IPMI snoop, we have a separate GPIO's and need to write the decoding mechanism for that. So we need to populate GPIO's and handle it via software.  That's the reason we handled this separately.

Is this not trying to do the same thing as https://github.com/openbmc/phosphor-host-postd/blob/master/7seg.cpp?

It just read the dbus and post it on 7segment, right?

As per the above comment both LPC and IPMI snoop are different.

Also, IPMI snoop supports mulit host postcode handling with host selector position. Based on the host selector position, corresponding host postcodes will be displayed in 7seg display. 

Please refer this design doc for more details.
https://github.com/openbmc/docs/blob/master/designs/multi-host-postcode.md
No. Here, we declared as raw only. In multi host systems, we append "1" to "N" with raw as raw1 or raw2 or rawN. In Single host systems we append "0" with raw as raw0.

show come this is different from 

constexpr char snoopObject[] ?
Ack. Updated snoopDbus with constexpr char[].
include this only for not get_option('snoop').disabled()
I tried to move this line to not get_option('snoop').disabled(), but getting CI issue as Unknown variable "libgpiodcxx" at line no.46 ( executable of snoopd ).
confirmed that the old snoopd support is not broken. I built it in bitbake and tested it otu.
Thanks for the confirmation and overall suggestions.
